title: Western Hemisphere
text:
The Western Hemisphere is the half of <a href="Earth">Earth</a> which lies <a href="west">west</a> of the <a href="prime%20meridian">prime meridian</a> (which crosses <a href="Greenwich">Greenwich</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>) and <a href="east">east</a> of the <a href="180th%20meridian">antimeridian</a>. The other half is called the <a href="Eastern%20Hemisphere">Eastern Hemisphere</a>. In geopolitical terms, the context in which the term is most often used, the "<a href="Encyclopedia%20Britannica">Encyclopedia Britannica</a>" defines it as "North and South America and the surrounding waters. Longitudes 20°W and 160°E are often considered its boundaries." It may be used in a <a href="cultural%20geography">cultural</a> or <a href="geopolitics">geopolitical</a> sense as a synonym for the "<a href="New%20World">New World</a>".
Toponomy.
As an example of , the term Western Hemisphere is widely used by some, such as the United States government, to refer to the <a href="Americas">Americas</a>.
Geography.
The Western Hemisphere consists of the <a href="Americas">Americas</a>, excluding some of the <a href="Aleutian%20Islands">Aleutian Islands</a> to the southwest of the <a href="Alaska">Alaskan</a> mainland; the westernmost portion of <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, both mainland and islands; the westernmost portion of <a href="Africa">Africa</a>, both mainland and islands; the <a href="Cape%20Dezhnev">extreme eastern tip</a> of the <a href="Siberia">Siberian</a> mainland and islands (<a href="Asian%20Russia">Russian Asia</a>); numerous territories in <a href="Oceania">Oceania</a>; and a large portion of <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.
The center of the Western Hemisphere is located in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> at the intersection of the <a href="90th%20meridian%20west">90th meridian west</a> and the <a href="Equator">Equator</a>, among the <a href="Gal%C3%A1pagos%20Islands">Galápagos Islands</a>. The nearest land is <a href="Genovesa%20Island">Genovesa Island</a> at .
The <a href="list%20of%20highest%20mountains%20on%20Earth">highest mountain</a> in the Western Hemisphere is <a href="Aconcagua">Aconcagua</a> in the <a href="Andes">Andes</a> of <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> at .
The tallest human-occupiable building or tower in the Western Hemisphere is the <a href="CN%20Tower">CN Tower</a>, which is located in <a href="Toronto">Toronto, Canada</a> at .
Proposed revision of hemispheric borders.
In an attempt to define the Western Hemisphere as the parts of the world which are not part of the <a href="Old%20World">Old World</a>, there also exist projections which use the <a href="20th%20meridian%20west">20th meridian west</a> and the diametrically opposed <a href="160th%20meridian%20east">160th meridian east</a> to define the hemisphere. This projection excludes the European and African mainlands and a small portion of northeast <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>, but includes more of eastern Russia and Oceania.
Sovereign states in both hemispheres.
Below is a list of the sovereign states in both the Western and Eastern Hemispheres on the <a href="IERS%20Reference%20Meridian">IERS Reference Meridian</a>, in order from north to south:
Below is a list of additional sovereign states which are in both the Western and Eastern Hemispheres along the <a href="180th%20meridian">180th meridian</a>, in order from north to south. (France is not listed below due to its inclusion above, though the meridian does pass <a href="Wallis%20and%20Futuna">Wallis and Futuna</a>.) With the exception of the United States (due to "<a href="Wake%20Island">Wake Island</a>", "<a href="Guam">Guam</a>" and the "<a href="Northern%20Mariana%20Islands">Northern Mariana Islands</a>"), all of them are located on just one side of the <a href="International%20Date%20Line">International Date Line</a>, which curves around them.
One sovereign state has territory in both hemispheres, but neither the <a href="prime%20meridian">prime meridian</a> nor the 180th meridian passes through its territory:

The following countries and territories lie outside the <a href="Americas">Americas</a> yet are entirely, mostly or partially within the Western Hemisphere:
